reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s operational definitions of “eutopia” (>0.9) and “mostly-great” (>0.5) and claims the main conclusion is an artifact of these cutoffs. This is somewhat central because the paper does use these thresholds to state/measure ‘fussiness’ and to make the ‘narrow target’ claim probabilistically; moving the cutoff can change the headline quantitative claim (centrality ~0.35). However, the paper explicitly notes the thresholds aren’t ‘magical’ and frames them as convenience markers on a continuous value scale; much of the argument aims to show value is fragile/steep near the top across many plausible views, which would often persist under alternative, decision-relevant thresholds. So the critique only modestly weakens the attacked component (strength ~0.25). Several statements are correct (the cutoffs are stipulated; a principled, decision-linked derivation would be stronger), but the critique overstates by implying the conclusions are largely artifacts and by asserting without support that at 10% “most views would be easygoing” (correctness ~0.6). It is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little filler.
title: Arbitrary threshold choices drive the model's pessimistic conclusions
